title: The State of Publishing and Live Ops

rawLines.text: [Music]
Welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast,
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games. We
bring together the industry's brightest
builders, investors, and thinkers to
keep a pulse on current events, dissect
emerging trends and games, share lessons
learned, and have a great time.
This podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services. For more information,
visit
[Music]
www.navic.co. This episode is brought to
you by Tik Tok's live ops program, which
is designed to help mobile game
publishers keep players engaged in
returning for more. In 2024 alone, Tik
Tok found 9x growth of live ops
campaigns on its platform, driving
dynamic in-game events, seasonal
updates, and post-launch content. By
leveraging Tik Tok's innovative
platform, publishers are able to enhance
player retention, improve engagement,
and ultimately boost in-game success.
Learn how Tik Tok can help your game
thrive by visiting Tik Tok's link in the
show notes. It's just one click away.
It's a super compelling program, so
definitely take the time to check it
out. This episode is brought to you by
Heroic Labs, which powers some of the
world's biggest games with its Heroic
game stack. Its composable products are
Nakama, the open- source back-end game
server. Hero, the game development
framework for all your live service game
features, including the complexity of
managing offline mode. Satori, the
worldclass live ops product for
maximizing monetization and retention.
And lastly, the heroic cloud to provide
massive scalability. After nearly 10
years of operation, thousands of studios
trust Heroic Labs to help them focus on
their games and not worry about game
tech or scaling for success. To learn
more and reach out, make sure to visit
heroiclabs.com or check out the link in
the show notes. Now, let's jump into the
episode. Welcome to the Noviet Gaming
Podcast. I'm your host, David Taylor,
and today we're going to take a dive
into the evolution of the games industry
through the lens of publishing and live
ops. My guest today has led teams
overseeing some of the biggest
commercial successes from MMO RPG genre
and has leveraged those experiences to
support dozens more through publishing
roles for Xbox Game Studios Publishing
and Arenaet. I'm delighted to welcome a
20-year veteran of the video game
industry and a close mentor of mine,
Kristen Cox. Kristen, welcome to the
podcast. Oh, thank you very much.
Uh, to kick us off, could you just give
us sort of a quick intro on your
background and how you got to where you
are today as head of publishing at
Arenaet? Yeah, absolutely. So, I think
like a lot of people in my generation,
my first gig in the video industry was
as a tester. Um, I was actually I went
to school for theatrical, scenic, and
lighting design with the idea that I
would work in film and television. And I
got out into the industry. I did start
working in film and television. But as
anyone who's worked in that space knows,
the beginning of your career is a bit of
a grind. So, I was doing really like
low-end work like indie movies and like
bad cable TV shows. And I wasn't loving
it. Um, and I needed a job between two
seasons of a bad cable TV show. And I
had a lot of friends who I'd gone to
school with who were like, "You are the
person in our group who loves video
games more than anyone else. Why don't
you go make video games?" And the
industry in in Los Angeles at the time,
the video industry was really booming.
But I had come from that generation that
was under the impression that programmer
was the only role in video games. And so
it hadn't really occurred to me. Um, and
I I did I found there was sort of a big
call for testers at THQ, which is where
I had my first my first job. And this
was in the day where it would be just
like hundreds and hundreds of testers in
a building just sort of throwing, you
know, hours at testing games blackbox
style. But I loved it. I had been very
frustrated in film and television. It
felt a little stagnant. There was a lot
of hierarchy. It didn't feel very like
flexible or creative at the time.
Reality TV was just starting to take
over. And the video industry, even from
the position of, you know, like a
contract QA person felt really new and
fresh, like there was a lot of
innovation, there were a lot of
possibilities, and I loved the people.
Um, and so I didn't go back to doing
film and television. I stayed in games,
you know, did some did some testing and
then was really lucky to get a job um as
a production coordinator because I had
this deep arts background. I went to
work for sort of an insourcing studio um
for NCOFT at the time that was doing art
insourcing for everything that NCOFT was
doing. And the head of that studio had
also come from film and television and
had an arts background and thought that
I would do well coming in to help with
production coordination. So that's where
I got my my first like um like in studio
position. Uh from there I had this you
know design training. That's what my
degree was in. And so I made a
transition over the next couple of years
into doing uh a sort of like hybrid of
production and design. Um, I pretty much
immediately, as I said, like my first
real gig at a studio was for NCOFT,
which made
MMOs. And I ended up staying in the MMO
space for a really long time. You know,
from NCOFT, I went to Disney and worked
with the team uh at Disney uh Walt
Disney Internet Group that did like
Toontown Online and the Pirates of the
Caribbean Online. And then from there um
I transitioned to work at Nexon. And I
had really wanted to work at Nexon. Like
I was very excited about what Nexon was
doing when I was at Disney. I was doing
a lot of competitive analysis um looking
at other MMOs that were aimed at a
younger audience. And there's very
little of that that gets made in the
West. Like Western game developers even
today don't really get super excited
about making games for younger
audiences. You see, mostly want to focus
on teens and then adults. So there was a
lot more um content aimed at a younger
audience coming out of Asia. And so I
had been playing a lot of Nexon's games
and was really excited about a lot of
the stuff that they were doing and their
sort of approach to MMOs or like we
called them virtual worlds a lot more
back then in the early 2000s. So I made
the jump over to Nexon and there I
learned just a ton. Um, I was working um
at the like sort of Nexon North American
office in Los Angeles and we were
handling uh publishing and development
and sort of managing live services and
live game direction for all of these
Nexon games, many of which had
originally been developed out of Korea,
but were now being operated for the rest
of the world. And while I was at Nexon,
I ended up uh eventually leading the
global Maple Story team, which uh which
operated Maple Story for basically
everywhere in the world that didn't have
another um another version of Maple
Story running. Uh so we did everything
except for Korea, Japan, Southeast Asia.
Um so our our focus was largely North
America, but we did service the rest of
the world. I did that for a number of
years. It was incredibly um educational.
I got exposure to just like a lot of
live ops games that Nexon was operating.
I got to do a lot of uh free-to-play
work, a lot of work on monetization and
a lot of work with deep data and data
analysis. But um I was mostly working
with a team in Korea. I was spending a
lot of time in Seoul. I was spending a
lot of time not operating in my native
language which was um very expansive and
I I don't regret it at all is I think a
wonderful experience but eventually I
kind of wanted to return to working with
a North American team and get a little
bit closer back to development. So I
left Nexon and went to Arenaet. Um and I
was at Arenaet for uh
um almost seven years. Uh I came in to
help them launch Guild Wars 2. Um, and
there at Arenaet, I I got a lot deeper
into working in design. I was a lead
designer and a game director there. I
focused on in-game economy,
monetization,
um, rewards, systems. Eventually did a
lot of design, leadership, and game
direction. Um, and then after my time
there had come to an end, I went I was I
kind of wanted to go back to publishing
because I missed having the larger
purview and getting to see lots of
different games and lots of different
experiences. I love Guild Wars so much.
Um, and loved working on Guild Wars 2,
but I I did spend, you know, almost
seven years working on one game. Uh, and
so I went over to Xbox Game Studios um
to work on the publishing side there
with like the goal to see a little bit
uh broader set of games in development.
And I got that. It was really wonderful.
I get to work on, you know, over a dozen
titles while I was there with a whole
bunch of different developers. And there
I focused a lot on strategy and also on
trying to help development teams
understand how to move from making sort
of consumed boxed products into making
live ops games because so many of the
teams we were working with at Xbox were
very traditional AAA developers um who
were now sort of grappling with the
reality of the industry where players
expect you to take care of the game
after it launches almost no matter what
kind of game you're making. And so I
spent a lot of time with teams there
helping them understand like what makes
live ops work and like how to approach
making games in a way players to engage
with for many years or like over a long
period of time. Um and I was there um up
until pretty recently. I I left Xbox
Game Studios um in October of last year
um to rejoin Arenaet. So I actually am
back at Arenaet now. Um I talked a
little bit before about how much I love
Guild Wars. was still so important to me
like creatively and such an important
part of my career and I love that
community so much. The opportunity came
up to go back to Arenaet and head up
their publishing division. Um I took it
and I I rejoined uh Arenaet at the
beginning of this year.
Awesome. And and for the folks
listening, uh I was on Kristen's team at
at Xbox and yes, we miss her dearly. Uh
we talk about it every week that we miss
Kristen. So um but happy that you found
something that uh is bringing you uh uh
equal if not more joy uh today.
Um so yeah I would love to sort of like
look at the live ops bit of your career
and then we can talk about publishing
later. Um but I'd love to sort of just
track the evolution of li of live ops in
the gaming industry over the last you
know 10 plus years. you've been sort of
playing an important role. How has that
evolved? Maybe through the lens of Maple
Story, which was obviously a massive
success on according to Wikipedia, it it
has generated $1.8 billion. So, you
know, that's a that is a um a whopping
success. Would love to hear sort of what
were the what was it like back then?
What was what was new? What was sort of
the the innovation that allowed for
Maple Story to be successful?
So much of it really comes down to and
this is I think the story of live ops is
the uh rising ubiquity of like always
connected to the internet um home
setups. Um there had been a little bit
more of it in Korea a little earlier. Um
both in the home, but also because
culturally there was so much more um
there was so much more of a tradition of
playing online games in a communal uh
space in a in a PC cafe. um that like
access to that like really like
high-speed broadband internet connection
was pretty accessible to people even if
they didn't have it in their home a
little bit earlier like in the late 90s
and like really early 2000s in Korea.
And so some of this innovation did come
a little bit faster out of um out of
like Korea and Japan. But we follow a
similar trajectory in the west where as
people got more and more access to
high-speed internet and were connected
more and more they were just getting
interested and starting to explore all
of these opportunities uh that are
created by that in the gaming space and
this idea of having always connected
virtual worlds or MMOs that are you know
they're continuing to progress and have
things happen in them whether whether
you're connected to them or not, they're
sort of a separate space that's always
on and always running. And as a player,
you just, you know, join into that world
whenever you have time, but it continues
to live and grow and change even when
you're not there. was something that had
been really interesting to game players
basically forever since the sort of
modern era of role- playinging games
with like tabletop RPGs like Dungeons
and Dragons or like war game or
miniature games was this idea that
there's a big world and you're stepping
into it to play but it might like have a
life of its own even when you're not
there. Some of the first um computer
games are MUDs, right? Like multi-user
dungeons that are textbased MMOs that
were getting developed as soon as the
internet was up and running. So, people
have been really interested in this for
a long time. Um there I think that
there's um a sort of natural um human uh
gameplay and desire for this kind of
experience. as I said, a world that kind
of persists when you're not there and
you step into it and play a role. Um,
and you know, it continues to go when
you're not there and you can meet
friends there, like make friends there.
But in the early 2000s, we started to
see graphics also come up and that
created another layer for players to
interact uh in a much more social way.
Um, text is great. Uh there's still MUDs
that are running today that do really
well, people are very passionate about.
But when we added in the layer of
visualization starting in like the late
90s and into the early 2000s, then we
really started to have people engage
with MMOs and virtual worlds in a way
that was like very social. It was about
having a presence there, like a virtual
presence that maybe represents you,
maybe it doesn't, but it's a virtual
presence that you can embody and then go
out and like engage in games. And that
is something that has been a strong
motivator for players from the
beginning. And I think what we've really
seen over the last 20 years is the rest
of video games um in the rest of the
video game space has sort of caught up
technologically um to being able to
deliver some of that in almost every
gaming experience that you have. um and
has just adopted those things because
they're so motivating to players and
they're so engaging for players that now
what we see is almost every AAA game
that you would play has some level of
that that they're trying to um put
inside of their game. Not literally
everyone. There are other genres that
aren't interested in this kind of thing,
but for people who are aiming for
mainstream success or like really broad
appeal, they are thinking about this
kind of desire and this level of
motivation that exists. When players can
engage with something where they're
like, "Wow, I'm like really embodying
this character and I'm really
experiencing a world that feels more
real. It feels more persistent. It feels
like something where what I do matters a
little bit more." Um, and so so much of
the video game industry has just been
this trajectory over the last 20 years
of more and more of the sort of broad
appeal AAA space adopting more and more
of those capabilities as technology has
just allowed it to happen, you know,
with just ubiquitous
broadband accessibility in the west now
and also like cloud and streaming and
all of these things that allow for more
and more of that to happen. Um, you
know, if you're making a video game, you
can do this at this point. And if you
can do it, you probably are at least
considering doing it.
Yeah, makes sense. So, what I'm curious
about is because, you know, technology
was sort of unlocking this uh new
capability, this new style of of
engagement and play. I'm curious if you
know when you were there doing the live
ops and the monetization, were there
sort of things that you guys were
testing out that were sort of setting
the stage for what live ops and
monetization would be for the next 10 to
15 years? I would say yes and no. One of
the interesting things about working so
early in virtual worlds and MMOs on the
PC side and working with a team um in
South Korea which had been sort of
pioneering a lot of this uh a lot of
this stuff. There were things happening
in the west, but um especially like
freeto play and that kind of
monetization was really being pioneered
out of the east was that we were looking
at a lot of player history and data back
in the early 2000s and we were
experimenting and trying a lot of things
with like how does engagement work? What
are we trying to
drive? How do we do
monetization? And I think I was a bit
lucky in a lot of ways to work with a
team at Nexon that was very long tail
focused, like extremely longtail
focused. There was this idea that if you
wanted to do microtransactions, the
trade-off that you were making was that
instead of getting a lot of money up
front and then, you know, hopefully you
satisfy and live up to the expectations
for the player, um, we're going to
invite the player in for free and
they're going to try it and then they're
going to decide if they want to pay us.
But they functionally can only pay us
little bits at a time. So if you don't
have repeat purchasing, you don't have a
business. Like if players, you know, pay
you once and then they don't ever pay
you again, you're not doing well. As
opposed to traditional, you know, boxed
product where actually if they pay you
once, even if they're incredibly unhappy
with the game, it doesn't really matter
to you from a business perspective.
Obviously, from a creative perspective,
it does. But from a business
perspective, you're like, well, I got
the money, like, you know, who cares?
Um, what happens next? But Nexon was
very focused on the long tale. Like
there was a lot of thinking and a lot of
the data and research that we did was
always based on like how do we keep
players happy for a really long time and
we very quickly learned that um you
really had to watch out and try to avoid
like binge spending like this was not a
good thing for longtail relationships.
Um and we were also dealing with a
younger population so we were always a
little nervous about any kind of like
massive spending because probably their
parents were going to be like wait what
are you doing now? I I I they would call
us and be like, "No, no, no, no. I don't
want you got to re you got to refund all
of this." Um, and so we were playing
around really early with a lot of like,
"Okay, how do we make this feel like
there's worthwhile things to buy, but we
don't want you to buy a lot of stuff all
at once, and we don't want you to get
into kind of a re like a binge spending
um cycle because we had all the data.
We're like, if people start spending
like massive amounts of money really
quickly, they'll be gone really quick
quickly. they almost never stick around.
Um, so is the insight that it is is the
is the insight there that it's like if
they spend a lot it's probably means
that their parents are going to like
shut them down and not let them play the
game anymore or is there some other like
what's the like insight around why
someone would binge spend and that would
cause them to churn. Oh, usually binge
spending is a behavior that uh leads to
regret. um like you you might be in a
mode where you're spending a lot but
then when you finish and you look back
at it and do like a value like
calculation a lot of times you be like
oo I shouldn't have done that and it
creates like a negative association with
the game and then you're like maybe I
should stop doing this altogether like
this isn't really like uh something I
want to continue uh doing or if you were
someone un you know who was a minor yes
your parents might step in and be like
you can't be doing this you can't spend
all this money we're going to you know,
get this re refunded or whatever. But we
also saw this with adults a lot like and
I still I see it quite a bit now even
like you got to be really careful if you
start to see like binge spending because
it usually means that they're about to
flare out of the game like there's
they're unlikely to stick around for a
really really long time. Um and so we
were just thinking a lot about Lawn
Tale. We were thinking a lot about like
how to keep players engaged for a long
time. We were thinking a lot uh too
about you know um operating for a
younger audience that they would age out
of the game and you know I thought
really interesting research was being
done around then really interesting
stuff. I was also getting a lot of
insight into different motivations in
different regions uh because culturally
you know Korea is not the same as the
United States and we had like different
things that uh people cared about or um
people felt was fair um in the way that
monetization was done. So that was
really helpful because I had a really
global purview uh because we had players
all over the world. Um I think that was
really helpful. So we were doing a lot
of this thinking and I feel like we were
really starting to figure out how to
create longtail relationships with
players in the west. Uh which was
different than the way that we operated
the same games in like Korea. Um, and we
were really starting to think about like
how to put a lot of our own internal um,
sort of um, policies in place to keep
things all running smoothly over the
long long term. We also grappled with
the stuff that most, you know, game
studios do like we like, you know, we
would get pressured to like hit your
quarterly goals and, you know, you maybe
want to make bad tradeoffs to do that,
but I think we were really grappling
with that in a pretty healthy way. And
then um do you have an example of like
um like a design choice that would lead
to a more healthy type of spend with the
longtail versus the binge spending?
Yeah. One of the things that was a big
goal, a big rule for us that I carried
through even after I left Nexon was like
never ask an angry player for money. Um
like you never want to associate anger
with spending money. uh because you can
get really short term like heightened,
you know, emotions that can lead to
short-term spending, but you're creating
a negative long-term um association with
the player and you're upsetting them.
Like there's a lot to be said too about
like just because a player paid you
doesn't mean they were happy to pay you.
Um and you really to be thinking about
that in the long term. Um so yeah, never
ask an angry player for money. Like if
something really frustrating just
happened to the player, they just lost
or like they just had a bad experience,
don't then be like, "Oh, do you want to
solve this with money?" Um, it's it's an
easy out in the moment, but it's a long
it's a it's a recipe for long-term churn
um from that player because you you've
maybe like activated also some like
sense of unfairness, right? Like
something bad just happened. Like you
see this in research all the time where
like when people lose a game, a
competitive game, um if you tell them
that they were playing against a machine
instead of a human, even if they were
playing against a human, they will um
assume that the machine cheated. And
even sometimes that the human cheated.
Um people are just we're just wired that
way. Like we don't like to believe that
we lost because of our, you know,
failings. Like we want to, you know,
find some external reason for it. And so
you activate this sense of unfairness a
lot of times if you if you're very much
in danger of activating that if you ask
players for money when they're mad. Um
which just isn't great. Um the other
thing that can be really rough and we we
were very cautious about this when I was
at Nexon. We were like never ever ever
should we let you like open a random box
and then like immediately push you right
back into another one. do not create
slot machine like experiences was like a
huge thing for us. We're like do not do
that. Like do not create a situation
where if you're rolling a random chance
we're like oh roll another one, roll
another one, roll another one. um
because you're really in danger of
creating a spiral like you you are
generating um and we looked a lot at the
gaming space and we're like okay don't
do stuff that they do like don't look at
stuff in the gambling space because you
are literally going to start activating
all of these sort of hardwired human
tendencies to like go down these spirals
and that could be really bad. Um, and we
just also didn't want the perception,
especially because we were making games
aimed at younger audiences, that we were
like trying to get them into gambling or
something, right? So, we a lot of these
hard rules um that I think were really
helpful.
Everything you're describing kind of
sounds like mobile games today. So I'm
I'm curious like are there is there are
those mobile games just being short-term
minded or is it just a different
audience different play style that
demand that has like different demands
on on the So I mean this is this is my
opinion right looking at this stuff as a
designer and and a live operations um
you know uh someone who's done a lot of
live operations and production like I'm
not an expert in mobile monetization but
yes my perception is that largely most
mobile games are very short-sighted like
and they don't think about having a a
three four year long relationship with
their players. I would also say they're
mostly optimized around appealing only
to people who want to spend really
massive amounts of money and not
appealing to people who want to spend
small amounts of money. This has been a
a trend and a something that the mobile
industry has had to grapple with in the
last 10 years is they were so anxious to
optimize and like you know AB test their
way into like really going after the
high
spenders. That's inherently a really
small percentage of your potential
player base no matter what you do,
right? There's only so many people that
are going to be happy or willing or able
to spend massive amounts of money on
your game.
So many mobile games, we're kind of
coming out of this a little bit. We're
in a different era now. A lot of things
have changed in mobile in the last three
or four years, but there was this era
where they were just really, really
focused on short-term gate. I mean, you
would like launch a mobile game,
optimize your way into identifying only
your highest spenders, churn everyone
else out, who cares about them, you
know, just milk it really hard and move
on after after a year, right? like this
is like very much the attitude for not
everyone. There's like some great mobile
games that think about the longtail.
There's some great mobile games um that
appeal to high spenders. there was a a
sort of conventional wisdom that built
up and this is actually why I say like
oh the work we were doing back when I
was working on like Maple Story or like
you know there were there was stuff
happening with like Gaia online or Haba
Hotel Club Penguin um even Ultima online
and stuff like that. I was like, "Oh,
was that setting the standard?" Sort of
in many ways, no. Like was very
fascinating. Like we were doing all of
these things. We were having a lot of
success um in the west as well. Like
people were constantly surprised by
this. The industry just wasn't really
ready to accept it. We would be like,
"Oh, we're we're killing it." Like we're
making tons of money off Western uh
players. We have a we had tons of
Western players.
But then um the sort of social games
happened like social like Facebook games
happened and mobile games happened and
that uh sort of um part of the industry
in the west came up almost entirely
removed from traditional MMOs even
traditional freeto-play MMOs and
honestly for me felt really bizarre like
it was like watching a group of people
operate in a similar space and make just
wildly different decisions then we had
been making and that we felt were best
practices that we were like these are
really like sort of counter to a lot of
the things that we think are best
practices based on years of experience
and we had had a lot of success but like
they really diverged those two lines of
design and ways of thinking about live
operations really really diverged
western mobile and um Facebook gaming
which didn't last for very long but
those but this very connected to what
like western live ops mobile games are
all about really went their own way like
and and sort of forged their own path
very much sort of through first
principles of trying to figure out like
how they wanted to um approach doing
these things. I think it's
understandable um when mobile and social
gaming first started um they were really
mostly very short session games and I
think that they legitimately were not
thinking about keeping people engaged
for you know 3 years four years you know
um to up to 10 years I don't think that
was on their mind at all so they had
very different incentives and very
different things that they were trying
to accomplish with their games and so we
really diverged and it's only I think
fairly recently that a lot of it is
coming that together and people who are
working primarily in like mobile are
starting to go like oh like maybe
there's some stuff that has been going
on in like PC or like longer session uh
traditionally longer session game games
